meta.description: Patient support dataset covering education, adherence, symptoms, journey mapping, and support programs

diabetes.overview: Diabetes is a chronic condition where the body cannot properly process glucose (sugar) in the blood. There are two main types: Type 1 and Type 2.
key_facts: Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition where the body doesn't produce insulin
Type 2 diabetes occurs when the body becomes resistant to insulin or doesn't produce enough
Common symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, and blurred vision

medications.name: Metformin
medications.purpose: Helps lower blood sugar levels by reducing glucose production in the liver
medications.important_notes: Take with meals to reduce stomach upset. Avoid alcohol while taking this medication.

medications.name: Insulin
medications.purpose: Helps cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream
medications.important_notes: Must be stored in refrigerator. Rotate injection sites to prevent skin problems.

lifestyle_tips: Monitor blood sugar levels regularly as advised by your doctor
Follow a balanced diet with controlled carbohydrate intake
Engage in regular physical activity (at least 150 minutes per week)
Maintain a healthy weight
Get regular check-ups and eye exams
when_to_seek_help: Blood sugar levels consistently too high or too low
Signs of infection (fever, wounds that won't heal)
Numbness or tingling in hands or feet
Severe symptoms like confusion or loss of consciousness

hypertension.overview: Hypertension is a condition where the force of blood against artery walls is consistently too high, which can lead to serious health problems.
key_facts: Often called the 'silent killer' because it may have no symptoms
Normal blood pressure is below 120/80 mmHg
Risk factors include age, family history, obesity, and lifestyle factors

medications.name: ACE Inhibitors
medications.purpose: Relax blood vessels to lower blood pressure
medications.important_notes: May cause dry cough. Avoid potassium supplements unless prescribed.

medications.name: Beta Blockers
medications.purpose: Reduce heart rate and blood pressure
medications.important_notes: Don't stop suddenly - taper off gradually. May cause fatigue initially.

lifestyle_tips: Reduce sodium intake (aim for less than 2,300 mg per day)
Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Limit alcohol consumption
Exercise regularly (at least 30 minutes most days)
Manage stress through relaxation techniques
Maintain a healthy weight
when_to_seek_help: Severe headache, chest pain, or shortness of breath

asthma.overview: Asthma is a chronic lung condition that causes airways to become inflamed and narrow, making breathing difficult.
key_facts: Symptoms can be triggered by allergens, exercise, cold air, or stress
Common symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath
Asthma can be managed effectively with proper medication and lifestyle adjustments

medications.name: Inhaled Corticosteroids
medications.important_notes: Rinse mouth after use to prevent oral thrush. Use daily even when feeling well.

medications.name: Bronchodilators
medications.purpose: Quickly open airways during an asthma attack (rescue medication)
medications.important_notes: Carry with you at all times. Use as needed for symptoms. If using more than twice a week, see your doctor.

lifestyle_tips: Identify and avoid your asthma triggers
Use a peak flow meter to monitor lung function
Keep rescue inhaler accessible at all times
Create an asthma action plan with your doctor
Get annual flu and pneumonia vaccines
Maintain good indoor air quality
when_to_seek_help: Peak flow readings in red zone
Difficulty speaking due to shortness of breath

depression.overview: Depression is a mental health condition characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest in activities.
key_facts: Depression affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities
It's a medical condition, not a personal weakness
Treatment typically includes medication, therapy, or both

medications.name: SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors)
medications.purpose: Increase levels of serotonin in the brain
medications.important_notes: May take 4-6 weeks to see full effects. Don't stop abruptly. May cause initial side effects that usually improve.

medications.name: SNRIs (Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors)
medications.important_notes: Similar to SSRIs but may help with both depression and anxiety. Follow doctor's instructions carefully.

lifestyle_tips: Stick to a regular sleep schedule
Engage in regular physical activity
Eat a balanced diet
Stay connected with friends and family
Practice stress-reduction techniques
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs
Set small, achievable goals
when_to_seek_help: Thoughts of self-harm or suicide (seek immediate help)
Symptoms not improving after several weeks of treatment
Substance use to cope with symptoms

tips: Set phone alarms or use medication reminder apps
Use a pill organizer with days of the week
Link medication to daily routines (e.g., with breakfast, before bed)
Keep a medication log to track when you take each dose
Ask family members to help remind you if needed
common_challenges: Side effects making you want to skip doses
Feeling better and thinking you don't need medication
solutions: Use technology: apps, alarms, smart pill dispensers
Simplify schedule: ask doctor if medications can be taken together
Discuss side effects with doctor - they may adjust dosage or switch medications
Ask about generic alternatives or patient assistance programs
Remember: medications work best when taken consistently, even when feeling well

what_to_track: Date and time of each dose
Symptoms before and after taking medication
Questions or concerns for your doctor
tracking_methods: Mobile apps designed for medication tracking

strategies: Understand why each medication is important for your health
Ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain how to take medications correctly
Discuss any concerns or barriers with your healthcare team
Keep medications in a visible, accessible location (but safe from children)
Review your medication list regularly with your doctor

symptoms_to_track: Blood sugar readings (fasting and after meals)
diabetes.tracking_frequency: Daily for blood sugar, weekly for other symptoms
red_flags: Blood sugar consistently above 250 mg/dL or below 70 mg/dL

hypertension.tracking_frequency: Daily for blood pressure, as needed for symptoms
red_flags: Severe headache with high blood pressure

asthma.tracking_frequency: Daily for peak flow, daily for symptom diary
red_flags: Rescue inhaler needed more than twice a week

depression.tracking_frequency: Daily mood check, weekly comprehensive review
red_flags: Thoughts of self-harm or suicide (seek immediate help)
Inability to function in daily life

symptom_diary_template.actions_taken: What you did to manage it

key_milestones: Blood sugar levels becoming more stable
Regular preventive care (eye exams, foot care)

programs.name: Diabetes Self-Management Education (DSME)
programs.description: Structured program to help patients learn diabetes self-care skills

programs.name: Diabetes Support Groups
programs.description: Peer support groups for people living with diabetes
programs.eligibility: Open to all people with diabetes and their families

programs.name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
programs.description: Evidence-based therapy to help change negative thought patterns
programs.eligibility: Anyone with depression, anxiety, or other mental health conditions

programs.name: Peer Support Groups
programs.description: Groups led by people with lived experience of mental health conditions
programs.eligibility: Open to people with mental health conditions

crisis_resources: Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741

programs.name: Chronic Disease Self-Management Program (CDSMP)
programs.description: Workshop for people with chronic health conditions
programs.eligibility: Adults with any chronic health condition

programs.name: Medication Therapy Management (MTM)
programs.description: Service to help patients get the most benefit from medications
programs.duration: Annual review with follow-ups as needed
programs.eligibility: People taking multiple medications or with complex conditions
